question: Question_02_(a)
statement:
Let

\[\displaystyle{}z=f(x,y)=\ln(4x^2+y^2)\]

Use a linear approximation of the function z=f(x,y) at (0,1) to estimate
f(0.1,1.2).
sols:
The linear approximation to a multivariable function $f$(x,y) at a point
(x,y) = (a,b) is given by L(x,y) where

\[\displaystyle L(x,y) = f(a,b) + f_{x}(a,b)(x - a) + f_{y}(a,b)(y - b)\]
where the subscripts denote partial differentiation with respect to the
given variable. In this case the partial derivatives of
$f(x,y) = \ln(4x^{2} + y^{2})$ are

\[f_{x}(x,y) = \frac{8x}{4x^{2} + y^{2}}, \quad f_{y}(x,y) = \frac{2y}{4x^{2} + y^{2}}.\]
and we wish to approximate $f$ near (x,y) = (0,1). Hence the linear
approximation we seek is:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle L(x,y) &= \ln(1) + 0\cdot(x - 0) + 2(y - 1) \\
&= 2y - 2
\end{align*} Using the linear approximation, we can estimate the value
of $f$(0.1,1.2) as

\[{\color{blue}f(0.1,1.2) \approx L(0.1,1.2) = 0.4}.\]
